results.headline: A Saloonkeeper Extraordinaire

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Toots

results.summary_short: Toots Shor’s name hasn’t lighted up a New York sign for more than 30 years, but thanks to Kristi Jacobson, his granddaughter, it will now grace movie marquees.

results.headline: On London’s Underside, Where Slavery Survives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eastern Promises

results.summary_short: Even as the turns of its narrative and the contours of its characters are recognizable, very little about “Eastern Promises” feels predictable or secondhand.

results.headline: Weekend Warriors

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darkon

results.summary_short: Every other Sunday, in the fields and playgrounds of suburban Baltimore, a medieval fantasy world materializes. That world is the subject of “Darkon.”

results.headline: A Challenged Existence and a Ray of Hope

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels in the Dust

results.summary_short: In “Angels in the Dust,” Louise Hogarth reveals a heart-wrenching facet of the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic by turning the camera on a group of innocent children in South Africa.

results.headline: Gym Class Becomes Boot Camp

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Woodcock

results.summary_short: Between Billy Bob Thornton’s wry performance and Tami Reiker’s nuanced photography, you half-expect “Mr. Woodcock” to deliver more than formulaic laughs.

results.headline: With a Song in Their Hearts, They Are Prey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great World of Sound

results.summary_short: “Great World of Sound” observes a sadder, tawdrier side of the self-deluding dream of fame.

results.headline: To Japan and Back for Eggs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silk

results.summary_short: “Silk” is the latest casualty in a line of films with a David Lean glint in their eye that aspire to elevated popular art but that come across as kitsch.

results.headline: A Determined Bipolar Dad in Search of Buried Treasure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King of California

results.summary_short: It is tempting to think of “King of California,” a serious comedy that does many things right, as a sequel of sorts to “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.”

results.headline: Art, Lost and Found

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rape of Europa

results.summary_short: The issues raised by “The Rape of Europa,” a documentary about the Nazi pillaging of art and the Allied effort to return it, can’t be conveniently consigned to the dustbin of history.

results.headline: Seeking Clues to a Son’s Death and a War’s Meaning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Valley of Elah

results.summary_short: Underneath the deceptively quiet surface of “In the Valley of Elah” is a raw, angry, earnest attempt to grasp the moral consequences of the war in Iraq.

results.headline: An Orphan of the Muggle Variety

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of December Boys

results.summary_short: In “December Boys,” Daniel Radcliffe takes a holiday from Harry Potter.  Too bad his destination is this treacly coming-of-age tale.

results.headline: Packing Heat After a Coldhearted Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brave One

results.summary_short: “The Brave One,” though well cast and smoothly directed, is just as crude and ugly as you want it to be.

results.headline: Out of His Navel and Into a Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ira & Abby

results.summary_short: “Ira & Abby” is a hard-working comedy of lust, therapy and Manhattan angst that deserves an A for ambition, if not achievement.

results.headline: Only Reality Is Discarded by a Pair of Pack-Rat Sisters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wool 100%

results.summary_short: Wild yet gentle, the fantasy film “Wool 100%” is a playful contraption illustrating the kinship between movies, fairy tales and dreams.

results.headline: The Life and Times of a Typeface

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Helvetica

results.summary_short: Overlong but fascinating, Gary Hustwit’s documentary posits Helvetica — a sans-serif typeface developed in 1957 — as an emblem of the machine age.

results.headline: Beauty and Art, Among the Dead in Paris

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forever

results.summary_short: Death, beauty and the persistence of art are the vast topics addressed in Heddy Honigmann’s frustrating documentary “Forever.”

results.headline: Blue Collar Guy Loses His Heart and Ruins His Lungs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Romance and Cigarettes

results.summary_short: There is more raw vitality pumping through “Romance & Cigarettes” than in a dozen perky high school musicals.

results.headline: When the Moon Was a Matter of Pride
results.display_title: In the Shadow of the Moon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Shadow of the Moon

results.summary_short: “In the Shadow of the Moon” is a morale booster. The power of its archival images hasn’t diminished with familiarity.

results.headline: The Warmth of Comfort Zones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bubble

results.summary_short: Vacillating provocatively between romantic comedy and political tragedy, “The Bubble” is photographed with a sunny brightness that belies the gravity of its intentions.

results.headline: In the Ol’ West, a Very Tough Commute

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3:10 to Yuma

results.summary_short: Russell Crowe and Christian Bale are the main reasons to see “3:10 to Yuma,” a serviceable addition to the current western revival.
